intro: Lucuma pyriformis, commonly known as the golden fruit or lucuma, is a South American native plant belonging to the family Brassicaceae. It is characterized by its large, yellow, egg-shaped fruits that are rich in nutrients such as carbohydrates, fiber, and essential minerals. The plant thrives in high-altitude regions with cool, temperate climates, typically growing in the Andean regions of Peru, Ecuador, and Bolivia. Its leaves are broad and lobed, while its flowers are small and white, often arranged in racemes. The fruit is harvested when fully mature, and it has gained popularity as a superfood due to its unique flavor and nutritional profile.
